body.p:
To His Excellency
B Magoffin
Dear Sir

Mr A H Talbott was fined at the last June term, of the Henderson Circuit fifty dollars, for selling whiskey to a slave. The proof in the case was in substance as follows Mr Talbott is a dealer in groceries of all discriptions, There was considerable excitement in the county at the time from apprehension of negro insurrection, in consequence of which there was a strong night police, a little after day light two negros were discovered standing not far from Mr Talbotts front door by the deputy marshall. Mr Talbott's house is on a corner, and the negroes broke as soon as they saw the deputy Marshall, one of them passing throught Talbotts house and leaving at the back door, The Marshall pursued caught the negro & found upon ^one^ a bottle of Whisky, There are ^on^ the square with Talbot several other grocery establishments all dealing in whisky --.

Mr Talbott is a highly respected
citizen and as far from violations of law as any in our community

For his standing and character we refer you to Grant Green & Judge Young -- I do not believe he was guilty, but upon the proof he was so found, but as I believe because of an universal feeling in thir community against the offense, It is but due to candour that I should say to you I was of course for Mr T. but I am ^not^ influenced in the least by that fact in thus writing to you
I honestly believe he was innocent & therefore ask a remmission
I ask your Excellency to regard & treat the above letter as my petition to have the fine referred to remitted, assuring your Excellency of my innocence

Henderson Cir. Ct
$50 } liquor to a slave
A. H. Talbott
Iss. Octo 10. 1861
